awd_titl_txt: Umpolung Methods with Electron Rich Aromatic Systems:  Aza-ortho-Xylylenes, and N,N-Dialkylaniline N-Oxides in Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Dr. William J. Chain of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Delaware. Dr. Chain and his team of students are developing new reactions of aromatic compounds that reverse the normal behavior of these molecules. The Chain group is manipulating normally electron-rich aromatic compounds chemically such that they behave as species with low electron density. This strategy temporarily changes the reactivity of these pi-systems and triggers the formation of new carbon-carbon, carbon-oxygen, carbon-nitrogen, and carbon-sulfur bonds that are found in compounds used in industrial, medicinal, and material applications. These studies are serving to train a diverse group of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in synthetic chemistry. The Chain group is also actively engaged in outreach activities in local elementary, middle, and high schools to promote science education and excitement towards STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) disciplines. 

While Friedel-Crafts reactions are well-established processes for aromatic substitution, there are still significant limitations in electron-rich settings. Professor Chain and his research group are addressing this gap in aromatic functionalization technology by developing ways to temporarily invert the reactivity of electron-rich anilines. In one approach, ortho-toluidines are being converted to aza-ortho-xylylenes (AOXs) via an electrochemical oxidation event and used as electron-acceptors for carbon-carbon bond formation. In a second approach, anilines are being oxidized to the corresponding N-oxides, which facilitates a wide array of bond formations and cyclizations that take advantage of the excision of the weak N–O bond. By virtue of the extremely mild reaction conditions associated with these new processes, the scope and application of umpolung reactions with electron rich aromatic rings is expanded thereby opening up new opportunities for organic synthesis. A better understanding of the fundamental reactivity behind these processes is also being established through collaborative computational studies. The educational plan is targeting outreach to local elementary, middle, and high schools with integration of high school students into the research program in the form of research internships.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our project has explored bond formations with electron-rich aromatic amines by virtue of a temporary inversion of reactivity. Generating and engaging highly reactive intermediates in a controlled and predictable manner by this strategy is a critical tool set in organic synthesis. Particularly powerful strategies in this regard are the manipulation of latent aromatic compounds via the temporary engagement of heteroatom-bound electron pairs and harnessing these energetic structures to form congested carbon–carbon bonds, carbon–heteroatom bonds, and polycyclic arrays.  During the course of the project, we continued our work to develop chemistry that leverages the reactivity of aromatic amines that takes advantage of labile nitrogen–oxygen bonds to drive the formation of strong carbon–heteroatom and carbon–carbon bonds.  We have also continued the development of cyclization events that are critically needed synthetic tools that are useful for the synthesis of myriad important organic molecules such as catalysts, pharmaceuticals, new materials and polymers, and other useful organic small molecules.  Our new chemical processes enable simple and direct access to a wide array of complex small organic molecules and has also provided an excellent opportunity for teaching the basic techniques and skills involved in organic synthesis, synthetic planning, and the structural characterization of organic molecules to undergraduate, graduate, and high school students.  The training of students in synthetic organic chemistry by its very nature includes the essential skills of strategic thinking, rational design, and problem solving.  Thus, students working on these projects are prepared for any number of academic and industrial chemistry-related fields of great importance.   

Students of all ages undertook the project research with an emphasis placed on enabling underrepresented groups of students in the Wilmington/Newark area of northern Delaware as well as in southern Pennsylvania.  During the course of this research, we continued working with chemistry instructors at local schools for regular classroom interactions, and recruited high school juniors and seniors for research at UD.  Our high school research participants contributed to and have authorship of the published manuscripts that resulted from the project.  We are also working to help a new non-profit organization in the city of Wilmington to engage young men and women at critical times in their lives in order to encourage them to pursue educational opportunities that might not otherwise have been available.  All our young interns have gone on to gain admission to competitive research universities and are continuing their studies by participating in STEM related research.  The graduate students involved in this research project have also received advanced degrees and have moved on to academic and industrial chemistry positions.   

 


Last Modified: 01/17/2025
Modified by: William J Chain
